content.title: Tibial and Peroneal Artery Anatomy
content.description: The three main infrapopliteal arteries supplying the leg and foot, originating from the popliteal artery trifurcation.

anterior_tibial.origin: First branch of popliteal, passes through interosseous membrane
anterior_tibial.course: Anterior compartment of leg, on interosseous membrane
anterior_tibial.termination: Dorsalis pedis artery on dorsum of foot
anterior_tibial.branches: Anterior tibial recurrent, muscular branches, anterior medial and lateral malleolar

posterior_tibial.course: Deep posterior compartment, behind medial malleolus
posterior_tibial.branches: Peroneal (from tibioperoneal trunk), circumflex fibular, muscular, posterior medial malleolar

peroneal.course: Along medial side of fibula, in deep posterior compartment
peroneal.significance: May be only patent tibial vessel; 'peroneal artery runoff'

angiosomes.at_ankle: Anterior tibial → dorsum, Posterior tibial → plantar/heel, Peroneal → lateral ankle
angiosomes.clinical_relevance: Direct revascularization to wound's angiosome improves healing

content.statement: Tibial and Peroneal Artery Anatomy is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Anatomy Lower-Extremity that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Tibial and Peroneal Artery Anatomy helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Tibial and Peroneal Artery Anatomy include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Tibial and Peroneal Artery Anatomy.
